reviewText: Love it
Love the style but it runs small and the arms are too short.

I rated this garment three stars because the fit is too questionable. Things you need to know BEFORE you buy:

1. It is NOT One Size Fits All/Most - this is ONE SIZE and you either fit or you don't. If you look like the model with slim shoulders and a modest bust, you've got a good shot at it. If you have broad shoulders OR are well-endowed in the bust area, it is NOT going to fit you. I got it for Christmas and this was my experience. From the bust down, the drape was lovely and flattering. From the bust up, it was so tight that it was uncomfortable.

2. The garment is LOVELY! The material is soft and the design looks great in person (at least the red one I got). I was very disappointed it didn't fit.

3. This company has its own website where you can read all the measurements for the garments they sell, just in the Amazon listing does not include them for some reason. The website is www.djtfashion.com for your information.

Hope this helps others not to be disappointed!
summary: It's One Size/Take Your Chances, but it sure is pretty!

This is a lovely top. Nice soft fabric, and not thin or cheap feeling. I am "curvier" on top, so while I could wear a medium in most tops, I buy a large. My own preference, I don't like anything clingy. I wear a ladies size 6 pant, but my weight is more in my middle area, so I buy large size tops. I'm about 5' 3", 116 pounds, if that helps...
That being said, this top fits more like an extra large to me. However, I'm keeping it because even though it's large-ish, the neckline isn't too big, deep, gaping. That's one thing I have a problem with is when I buy tops in a size large, often the neckline is so big, shows my undergarments, and just looks tacky. Sometimes I can take in the neckline, most often I just have to pass on buying the top. So I was very happy that this top's neckline fits just fine. Plus it's such a pretty design.

reviewText: Really lovely sweater.  Good quality fabric.  Can't wait to wear it out.  I'm sure there will be compliments.  Am pleased.
Nice

The quality of this top is quite good.  Many reviewers have said that it's not too thick and not too thin -- and I'd add that the thickness is just right.  The fabric is some kind of knit, similar to what you might find on a sweatshirt.  The result is that it drapes pretty nicely and has some structure (if are trying to hide a muffin top or tummy rolls, this top would successfully do it), despite its flowy design.  I bought the khaki color and I like the color a lot.  I love how comfortable the top feels when I wear it.  But I returned it.  I think this top would look lovely on someone who has a slimmer torso and maybe a smaller chest.  I am a 38C with wide shoulders and slimmer hips (some might categorize me as an apple, but I think I'm a bit more pizza shaped) and when I wear this top I think I look like I'm putting on maternity wear or I could be a linebacker trying to appear delicate.  Either way, it's not a good look for me.  A wider neckline might have improved it.
summary: Pretty good quality, but not a good look for apples or pizza

And overall, I was too warm on the plane since it's more like a light sweatshirt material than a t-shirt. The bottom is a bit flared, but not enough to look hippy, and the cloth was very comfortable.

I've wanted to own a Wool Cape for a really long time. I was absolutely thrilled to realize that they were coming into fashion, and immediately went on the hunt for one. Being from the Midwest, the winters get bone-chillingly cold, and I spend much of my time walking across a cold college campus through snow and ice.

The coat recently arrived, and I'm thrilled. The fabric is soft, and heavy enough to ward off the chill. With a sweater and a thick scarf, it keeps most of the cold off. The buckles are nice and solid, and there are two extra snaps along the front to keep it closed. The hood is even better, and does well with keeping the wind from my face.

Though the package did take a while to arrive, I was pleased when it arrived earlier than expected (Especially since the snow's started falling)!

Women deserve underwear that fits as expected and is decently designed and constructed. Misogyny towards fat women is especially insidious and egregious. These underpants are an act of hate. In a size 14, these underpants are supposed to correspond to hips 60-63.5", or a dress size 34-36. However, they are so absurdly small that they might only fit a panty size 9, equivalent to a dress size 14-16, with hips 45-46.5". Worse, unlike most cotton jersey or interlock panties, the strangely stiff and scratchy fabric has little or no crosswise stretch. The crotch piece is about 1.5" wide, which would hardly be wide enough for panties for an eight year old girl, much less the dimensions of a plus size woman. Nor is there enough length for a full cut panty. The manufacturers seem to think that as we get bigger, we do so only in width and not in length. They seem to think that large women have big backsides and completely flat tummies. The result is a supposedly full cut panty that is actually more like a tiny, wierdly fitting bikini with a waistband far south of the anatomical waist and inadequate coverage front and back. The quality of plus size underpants has become worse and worse. I give up. I'l just sew my own.

For the price, this wristband is very nice looking at a very affordable price. However, it suffers from a couple issues:

1) The rolled end links are too small for a watch (such as the Seiko 007) with fat spring bars. As mentioned by a previous reviewer, this issue is pretty easy to overcome by using the tines of a dinner fork to pry the rolled end links to fit the bars. The process took just a few minutes. However, I was left questioning the integrity of the rolled ends and concerned the spring bar might slip out at some point in the future.

2) It's not comfortable. I was able to wear the strap for three days before I noticed chaffing on my wrist and had to take the watch off. I'm not looking to push through the pain and develop calluses on my wrist, so for me, this was a deal breaker. I will be exploring other wristband options.
summary: this wristband is very nice looking at a very affordable price

reviewText: Was quite surprised with the quality at the price and the ease of changing the band.

Looks looks great, and is easy to install and resize. Getting just the right fight might take a few attempts, but it is a lot easier than removing links on a bracelet. I put it on a Casio Dive Watch and get a lot of compliments now. It's a great and affordable way of improving the look of a watch.

I was pleasantly surprised by the high quality of this bracelet. The finished ends that attach to the watch case look more refined to me than the shark mesh link style bracelets with raw end links.

The overall polish is very good, And the link thickness has a nice, solid feel, with just enough texture to them to add visual interest. I was concerned about the latch, but it works very well, has a finely brushed finish, and looks great on this bracelet.

The photos are the 22mm bracelet on a 44mm dia. Seiko SPC131 on my 8 inch wrist. I used the original Seiko bars that came on the watch with no problems.
Good quality good for the price
quality and price is Amazing

I am a fan of shark mesh watch bands. They offer a lot of comfort and flexibility that you don't have from many metal link bracelets. Plus they harken back to the glory days diving tool watches like Rolex Submariners, Zodiac Super Sea Wolves, and Seiko 007's. The 70's style added a bit of flash to the diver watch.

I wanted to harness a little bit of that gaudy old school cool. I bought myself a Seiko SKX007. An inexpensive and classic diver. It had some vintage potential, but the stock rubber strap left a lot to be desired.

Enter the shark mesh band. After installing it on the 007, it drips 70's style. It has less bulk than a metal link bracelet.

Fit and finish are excellent for a $10 band. To adjust the size, you need to pry up the flange on the inside of the clasp. You slide it to where you want it and clamp it back down.

As a warning, make sure you have the clasp hooked correctly, or you'll lose it. It doesn't have the second safety clasp over top. There's a set of hooks the hook over a bar and the cover clasp snaps over it. I have worn it running and lifting stuff and it has never unhooked.

Overall a great way to put a heavy dose of 70's era style on your desk diver. Would highly recommend.
